results.title: Management and supervisory skills
results.brief_description: Using a case study, this program looks at examples of poor supervisory and management skills such as poor delegation, improper use of authority, and being a poor role model. Conversely, it looks at the factors which contribute to good management, such as; effective business planning and review, accurate record keeping, identifying performance indicators, setting realistic goals and objectives, open communication, cost control, continuous training, and promoting confidence and respect in the work place. The guide which accompanies the video outlines the key areas of planning- setting objectives; controlling costs; improving methods and making decisions.

results.title: Management
results.creator_credit: Mutual Film Corporation and Career Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Is this your career series”.
Illustrates what management is, using as an example, a well run household. A manager needs to ensure that all the activities of an organisation or business enterprise combine effectively. They have the ultimate responsibility for an entire organisation - its success or failure. Points out that most careers can lead to management but that school leavers can train in technical colleges, universities or sometimes within an industry.

results.title: Man: the polluter
results.brief_description: A richly illustrated cartoon film that enlarges on man’s capacity to foul his own nest, and to ignore it. Made by a joint team of Canadian and Yugoslav animation artists, the film transmits its warning with unflagging humour, imagination, movement and design. In between animated sequences Dr Fred H. Knelman, Professor of Science and Human Affairs, Concordia University, Montreal, comments on the import of what is shown and on what lies in store if more responsibility is not taken on a global scale to conserve what is left of our vital resources and useable environment.

results.title: Man: one family
results.creator_credit: British Ministry of Information and Ivor Montagu
results.brief_description: A refutation of the Nazi theory of the “master” race, this film shows scientifically that there is no basis for the common and persistent belief that there is such a thing as race superiority. The film was translated into sixteen different languages for use in liberated Europe after World War II.

results.title: Man: a course of study
results.brief_description: The course of study is designed for upper primary or lower secondary level but can be introduced effectively at any level. It deals with the basic questions: What is human about human beings? How did they get that way? How can they be made more so?

results.title: Man, monsters and mysteries
results.creator_credit: Ken Peterson, Walt Disney Productions and Les Clark
results.brief_description: Discusses how humans invented monsters through fear and ignorance and how science attempts to unravel these mysteries. Looks at the history of the Loch Ness Monster. Partly animated. Suitable for primary level.

results.title: Man Without Pigs
results.creator_credit: Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies, Australian National University. Research School of Pacific Studies and Chris Owen
results.brief_description: John Waiko is the first Papua New Guinean to reach the status of professor. After receiving his doctorate from the Australian National University he travelled back to his village on the Gira River to celebrate, taking with him a film crew and Hank Nelson, his academic supervisor. The film documents his struggle to perform the required ritual correctly.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Institute of Papua New Guinea Studies, Australian National University. Research School of Pacific Studies and Chris Owen

results.title: Man with a movie camera [Special edition]
results.brief_description: Writer/Director/Editor, Dziga-Vertov, was made Head of the Cinema Department of the All Russian Central Executive at the age of 22. His film shows all the tricks of which the camera is capable. Vertov shows Russia as it really is; indeed, the final impact of the film arises from a feeling of participation in life itself as we share the unique vision of the camera-eye. This special edition runs the film twice. The first version is the original silent one, with a musical score composed and performed by the Alloy Orchestra. The second version contains a commentary by Yuri Tsivian, a leading historian in Russian silent cinema.
